abstract: Rising oil prices raise questions about whether G.M. has improved enough to turn an adequate profit on smaller cars.
snippet: Rising oil prices raise questions about whether G.M. has improved enough to turn an adequate profit on smaller cars.
lead_paragraph: The Middle East is giving General Motors its first big test since it left the junkyard. As shares of G.M. hover at their November initial public offering price, investors are not forgetting what happened when oil prices surged last time around. When crude prices in the United States reached $100 a barrel in 2008 — a level they returned to this week — G.M.’s profit center in trucks and sport utility vehicles took a big hit.

headline.main: Mideast Turmoil Is First Test for New G.M.

byline.original: By ANTONY CURRIE and IAN CAMPBELL
